All my own work (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Shows how new approaches in art education in Victoria can be successfully applied in the classroom. As the new course is child-centred, the film visualises some of the environmental influences that children experience

results.title: All my own work
results.brief_description: An in-service education film for teachers. Aims to show how the new approaches in Art Education can be successfully applied to the classroom. The emphasis is on painting, while the new course is child-centered.

results.title: All lit up
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Joy Batchelor and Gas Council
results.brief_description: An exhilarating presentation of the story of the use of fire for warmth and comfort since the days of the Romans. Shows something of the inherent problems that have persisted until today; with the use of an ingenious yet simple invention, the major difficulties have been solved.

results.title: All in a day
results.brief_description: Filmed at Bradfield Park in New South Wales. The film shows how children can create their own world even in adverse situations. The children’s centre interests young people from pre-school to teenage in painting, drama, dancing and other social activities.

results.title: All I Need Is You

constellations_other.name: Now watch this
constellations_other.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

results.description: The music video, directed by Richard Maxwell, by Rab Cantor, off his album Not a Trampoline.

results.title: All down history (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Nick Brenton, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Special Needs in Education”.
Looks at the history of Mongolism and school provision for Down’s syndrome children. Compares a school for severely subnormal children with a high proportion of Down’s children, with a school for children with moderate learning difficulties and two Down’s children, and finally with a local comprehensive school with one Down’s child

results.title: All about weightlessness: the astronaut's dilemma
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Dr Heinz Haber uses a specially created cartoon character, Homo-Sapiens-Extrater-Restrialis, to explain the hazards of survival in the strange environment of outer space. Man must become conditioned to living in a state of weightlessness for long periods. Eating presents some new and surprising problems; sleeping will be a unique experience. We do not know how man’s subconscious mind will react to prolonged journeying through space. An excerpt from “Man in space”.
